reviewText:
Remove the sword from your stomach, turn on the Karaoke machine, pull out those unwashed schoolgirl panties and get sniffin' because Shogun 2 is finally here!  All the shame you feel from dishonering your family will be washed away when you are immersed into the experience that is Shogun 2!

Feel your innter girly side by being bombarded with countless cherry blossoms...Relive the glory days of Japan before the thing that is left out of most Japanese textbooks happened...March your armies to victory with more efficiency than the Bhutan death march...Build the most glorious railroad since the Burmese railway, but with less slaves...Pwn and r4pe your enemies  more than the city of Nanking...and destroy your enemies harbors more than Pearl Harbor!  The experiences and playstyles are endless!

In all seriousness though here is my actual review....above was just my promotion of the game..

I could never get in to any of the other Total War games.  I played both Rome 2 and Empire a bit, but eventually stopped playing them after a game or two.  I find this game way more fun to play and I think it is way better to look at.

Here are some reasons why I think this is the best newer Total War game..

-Balance.  The other Total War games can become confusing with the huge amount of other units...It takes way too long to figure out what counters what.  In this game, it is quite simple but still complex at the same time.  Horse beats archer, archer beats soldier, soldier beats horse...this rock, paper, scissors forumula makes it easy to pick up and learn.  There are still other units that add complexity, but for the most part you can rely on trusting this simple formula

-Design/Graphics.  Rome 2 might look slightly better in terms of polygon count and effects, but not by much.  This game looks better overall though!  The Japanese artwork and music throughout the game really helps to immerse you.  Everything else looks nearly identical to the new Total War games, but this runs better and has better performance.

-Decent unit movement, control, and COLLISION DETECTION!  One of the main reasons I always got sick of the other Total War games was because it always felt that you wern't in control of your units or armies...A group of 40 soldiers, essentially acted like one unit.  This game still isn't like other RTS games where you have control over a single unit...a single unit is still considered an army, but this concept has been improved and is actually better than it is in Rome 2.  Sending in a group of 30 or so soldier in Total War games was always lame...the individual soldiers would kinda just walk around the enemies not doing anything and every 5 seconds you would eventuall see one of your units hit someone with a sword.  This is only really a problem with melee units, but its a really big problem because it make it feel like your units arn't fighting right.  Its still an issue in this game, but units are much more likely to engage eachother in battle and not just walk around not doing anything.

-The expansion!  Usually expansions in Total War games or other RTS dont really change the gameplay that much.  The expansion in this game almost turns it into a whole other game!  Without the expansion, you are just using mainly archers, sword, horses, and other simple weapons....but by installing the expansion you upgrade the technology of the Japanese by like 500 years!  This is mainly because Japan was feudalistic before the arrival of western powers...The introduction of such different weapons and technologies would seem out of place usually, but in this historical context it makes sense!  It really changes the game a lot, and it makes both versions of the game fun to play.

Way better than any other Total War game I have played...which is medieval 2, empire, and Rome 2.  A great game which you can always come back to!  Tons of cool MOD support, like one where they add tons of blood and decapitations!  Awesome!

8/9 Sudoku boxes!

reviewText:
In my opinion Shogun 2 is the best Total War game to date. This game does have bugs and sometimes pisses you off but it is still a really good game. I'm sorry for the length of this review buyt I wanted to give you an in depth feel of the game.

Good

1) The game allows you to do whatever you want with your empire. If you want to set the Takeda Clan's land on fire, you can. You want to assassinate a general that is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off? You can. Do you want to be a cold ruler and kill your own subjects if they disagree with you? You can (With consequences). Do you want to build a huge trade empire? You can. You get the picture.

2) It looks good, not amazing compared to today but back when it was made people were like DAMN!!!!"

3) All combat in the game was animated using real-life sword masters therefore it looks amazing

4) Large scale battles. While on the campaign map you control your empire
date: but when you go into combat with another army it is a whole different story. You have thousands of soldiers (all animated
recommended: and looking unique) fighting each other at one time with cavalry charges
hoursPlayed: gunfire
voteText: arrows flying everywhere
helpfulPercent: and even mortars in the later stages of the game. While this is going on you have the morale factor
votesHelpful: if a regiment sees allies routing
votesTotal: starts loosing a lot of men
votesFunny: is set on fire
commentsCount: is surrounded
column16: or if the commander dies they loose morale which leads to them being less effective in battle and if it gets too low they will break (They will run away for a short amount of time)
column17: and if it gets worse than that the unit will be shattered (They will run from the battle and can no longer be controlled).\n\n5) Meaningful allies. I found that in most of the other Total War games your allies don't help much or all out betray you all the time. In Shogun if you ally with another clan and start a war with another clan
column18: they will amass an army to help you. They may also trade with you or give you military access to their territory.\n\n6) Familty trees. You have the ability to arrange a marriage with another clan if you have an unmarried woman in your family. As time progresses new family members are born and after a few years in-game they become adults ready to marry or command an army (Each have their own skills
column20: and personality). You may also adopt generals into your army and make one of your best family members your heir (It is chosen for you in most Total War games).\n\n7) Huge map. Shogun 2 features a huge detailed campaign map filled with cillages
column24: etc. There are also 25 - 30 clans to dominate on the map each with their own buffs and weaknesses.\n\n8) Naval battles. This is the first game in the series with naval battles. Basically you have a fleet of ships with a certain amount of archers and infantry on each ship
column25: each ship has their own speed and strength of their hull. The battle either ends when you set the enemy ships on fire using flaming arrows or bomb throwing ships
column26: or by boarding the ship and letting your infantry fight (This makes the crew surrender on the enemy ship if you are successful
column27: adding a new ship to your navy).\n\n9) Avatar conquest. This is the main multiplayer mode of Shogun 2. You create a general
column30: and invade territory on the conquest map. You also build your own army
column31: and if a unit sees a lot of battles you can make them veterans allowing you to color
column33: and upgrade them. You attack other players using the army you created and are ranked on the leaderboards.\n\n10) DLC. There are multiple DLCs that add new units to the game
column34: and one that makes it bloodier. The two large DLCs are Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai. These are based in different time periods than the base game and add new units
column35:
factions and a new story.

11) No real noticeable bugs that I can think of


Bad

1) At times units will loose morale and run even if they were about to win the fight

2) Some units in the game are unbalanced and can easily destroy most of your army



Well now that you know the good and bad about the game hopefully you have decided on whether or not to buy it.

As for my rating I give this game a 10/10

reviewText: Total War: Shogun 2 is a Turn based strategy game based on 16th century in Japan. Time that most people call the Edo Period". Period with mainly only wars
recommended: pain and sorrow. A time when almost every bigger clan was battling to gain their place on the "throne". Every clan wanted their Daimyo to become a Shogunate.\n\nIn Total War: Shogun 2 (I'll just say Shogun 2 from now on) your objective is to rise your fame by conquering other clans and province

voteText: Shogunate was like a "king" in Japan. "The ruler of them all".\n\nIn Shogun 2 you can chose almost any of the strongest clans that existed in the Edo Period.  And if you ask me

reviewText:
This game has stolen more hours from my life than any other game in my library; why?
The Total War series has been the LEGACY for strategy games in the past two decades and I can certainly see why.
I have played for every clan in this game thus far and still havent beaten it, the AI learn very well considering the time this was made, also I like to play on hard >.>
But yeah if you're a casual player or a hardcore strategy game sado-masochist, PLAY.
I dare you to play an entire campaign without raging at the AI for destroying a beloved army or agent.
One thing that STILL DOES need work; Allies should be ALLIES, not 'Heightened Peace Treaties'. If you are new to this game DO NOT feel like your allies will have your back, they will sit by and watch your lands crumble then vulture their way in. That is pretty much my only piece of advice.
This game has sucked up so much of my time and with a great deal of reason. I love this game like I love bacon <3

reviewText:
THe last TW I played to death was Medieval 2. I played Empire and NTW briefly but got bored. That being said, here's a few reasons why I think this game is a winner.

It looks amazing even 4 years on. Not just the battlefield graphics, but the effort they put into music and aesthetics which makes Shogun 2 really unique and immersive. The campaign map is a serene mix of handrawn maps and little 3D communities and towns, forests that change colour in the autumn, fields that freeze over in the winter.  Everything is represented as drawings and paintings. Units communicate in Japanese. It's polish like this that shows CA went the extra mile.

On the battlefield it also looks amazing. The individual choreographed fights among thousands of detailed soldiers is incredible, I've never seen anything like it before in a strategy game.

AI is decent. Not amazing, but not brain-dead either. They use cavalry quite well to surround you and get behind your lines. They know when to attack vs. defend on a hill, and support weakened units with reserves. However I've found they're too quick to charge into battle even when they're at a disadvantage. EIther way I get a good challenge.

There are very clear advantages/disadvantages between unit types, terrain, weather etc. so you can quickly formulate tactics and strategies.

Campaign-wise, I find it's the same old as previous TW games. Attrition and seasons add a nice strategic layer: you can't always afford to starve out cities but storming them will always be costly.

I really can't think of any major problems with this game. 9.5/10.

reviewText: Really love this game. If you have played other total war games before and haven't tried this one I will let you know up front the game mechanics are some of the best in all of Total War history. It's been a long time since I have played a TW game where playing on the defense of a seige has been so fun that I always look forward to it. Religion plays a much bigger role than in some previous titles and causing Religious Unrest can really be a fun way to stick it to your enemies. This game also has neat little cut scense for when your Ninja assassinates someone, commits arson, or fails in the attempt. Even if your ninja fails you might end up laughing at how pathetically bad they are if not yet trained up. This game gives you all new challenges. Will you stick to honor and tradition and the old ways? Or perhaps honor means nothing to you and the old ways must go! You might even adopt firearms to turn the tables on rival clans! Do you want samuarai or some bad ♥♥♥ crazy monks? Both are equally bad ♥♥♥! Perhaps you will lead the Religious Zealots and Peasants of the Ikko Ikki to victory, swarming your foe with vast numbers of peasants and rogue samurai (Ronin). Well who is to say? The choices are your's! The future of Japan is now in your hands!

reviewText:
Fun game...until you realize the AI cheats BADLY and can spawn impossible armies out of nowhere.

1st, the AI gets more recruitement slots. So it can pull entire armies out of thin air.

2nd, the AI can't manage its economy, so instead most of the factors don't apply to it. It pays almost no upkeep, and it can never go bankrupt.

3rd, the AI's don't play to win, they play to kill you. So as soon as they declare war they'll take everything they have and run it at you. At which point, being entirely defenseless it'll lose to another AI player, which after a few turns will declare war on you. Rinse-repeat the rest of the game.

4th, the AI's get unlimited generals, which they will chain suicide at you.

5th, the AI gets massive moral and economic boosts in very hard and legendary.

Overall a decent game...minus the cheating.

reviewText: Awesome game that goes back to the origianl Shogun: Total War formula, you can feel the influence of Sun Tzu's Art of War all over it. Katana's clash, bombs are thrown, flintlock muskets are fired, and throats are slit by shinobi in the night. The Battle AI is finally competent enough to make use of forests for ambush and avoid charging directly into your spearmen across the bridge, and finally put up a decent challenge to your forces. In Direct X 11 mode, the game looks absolutely superb, a big step up from Napoleon, and uses the new form of anti aliasing called MLAA created by AMD, which increases performance. Multiplayer is engaging, and the coop mode is simply fun to play with a friend. Now, maybe if the game didn't SINGLE THREAD in Direct X 11 mode, and we didn't have to pay for the factions already in the game as DLC, this would have been a near-perfect game.

reviewText:
This is an excellent game set in the Sengoku Jidai period of Japan. For me, the campaign proved to be challenging but not tedious. I recommend this to wargamers.
This game is more balanced as the effects of spear, cavalry, and sword units are more obvious than other games in the Total War series. You will have access to the same base of units as your enemy, but its not really a bad thing as there are enough nuances to each faction. Likewise, a bone-headed cavalry rush into a spear unit will skewer cavalry with confidence, though with no certainty. Likewise, spear units will die at the hands of sword units, and so on. The key in winning therefore is knowing what unit to commit in an action. A reserve is helpful in exploiting gaps in enemy lines or plugging holes in your own.
The game is not without its faults; the chief complaint I have is that the AI loves to spawn little armies that wreck a little havok in your lands but offer little challenge in a pitched battle. The campaign AI is worse as its diplomacy is still vague. Strangely, though the AI offers a good challenge in hard or higher setting, its predictability in patterns of attack and consolidation of its forces cheapens my sense of accomplishment. It would have added a little flavor and attention to detail if an enemy general with a supposed penchance for cavalry rush do so rush me its cavalry reserve as a coup de main. The enemy agents are OK and add a little unknown factor that adds immersion into the game. But I digress...
This game is best enjoyed with your friends. A match with friends or even strangers will give you that added flavor and quirks that make you come back for more. The Shogun 2 community is good, and often welcoming to new players willing to listen to veteran gamers.
Long story short, what you find lacking in the singleplayer campaign you will get in the multiplayer.

reviewText:
[This review is for TW: Shogun 2 - Fall of the Samurai.]

My hours played speaks for itself. 1,000+ hrs played and I still come back to this game. Rome II has been out for almost a year and I just couldn't get into it the same way.

I love the 'family tree' feature in this game. Being able to look back at the end of a long campaign, with my Daimyo(clan leader) now 53 yrs old, having started the game when he was 18, it's a great feeling. To remember the past battles, close calls, the sacrifices etc.  It really helps build that immersive connection, so that you actually care about your clan and your armies.

Like all games, this one isn't perfect. The multiplayer could be better. I'm a big stats type of guy with a game like this, and I really felt like the end of game stats weren't as informative as they could have been. For example, when you look back through the history, it says Won battle on this date"
date: but that's it. I wish it said which general and included all of the stats for that specific army

reviewText:
Total War is a series that has intrigued me, but frightened me off just the same. The difficulty in learning what unit does what, and how each operate was a very difficult task, but learning to overcome that uncertainty pushed Shogun 2 into a limelight that it's easier predecessor (Empire) held.

Shogun 2 provides a mixture of well-designed characters with extremely detailed animations into deadly historical war. In true Total War fashion, just having superior numbers and zerging" an enemy unit does not always win. It's the proper use of the right "tool" to do the job that prevails here.

It does take a LOT to get used to
date: and it takes awhile to get into the "swing" of things
recommended: but give it enough time and you will be stroking your chin in thought as you effectively play your real-time chess against an opponent that already knows your army better than you do."

reviewText:
TW: Shogun 2 is by far one of my favorite games. The reasons being the balanced units, co-op, multiplayer, the excellent expansion that is Fall of the Samurai, unique and interesting bonuses for the majority of the clans, well placed tactical structures  on the maps, a very well designed skill tree that scales into late-game, and the manual battles are something else.

However as much as I could praise any positive attribute i've previously stated in detail, i've no intention of doing so. You'd be better off not having what the game has to truly offer being spoiled. Which leads me to the negative attributes of TW: Shogun 2 because I will go into a bit of detail, and you should definitely know what you're getting into because realistically what is a minor complaint for me could be a major problem to you. Specifically within the standard campaign diplomacy is for the most part a joke. The player has options to increase their diplomatic standings with another clan, but you will face situations where neighboring clans refuse nearly all attempts at diplomacy and ultimately on the higher difficulties this means going to war early with 4 or more clans. The only ways to avoid this are to pay other clans off and/or hope you can set up a prearranged marriage, and realistically both are not an option in the early game phase. Well that or you have to choose a clan that is positioned in a corner or the Chosokabe which are on a small island. Now if you reach a certain point where you've gained too much territory there will be a realm divide and you instantly lose about 250 diplomacy with all clans meaning you're instantly at war with every remaining clan in Japan unless you've been paying them off until that event happened, and even still it's meaningless to pay that clan off because no matter what you do they'll eventually go to war with you anyway due to the fact you lose a large amount of diplomacy every turn after a realm divide. Essentially within the standard campaign at a difficulty of 'hard' or higher, the diplomacy mechanic within the game is what will literally make your life a living hell  and it gets worse as you bump up the difficulty. That isn't to say you can't win, but unless you're either willing to play co-op or sacrifice much of what you've conquered for a better tactical position you can and will be completely crushed losing all time invested in playing. Regardless though the game can still provide a challenge at normal difficulty for some time, and the hard difficulty isn't going to give you nightmares if you're well versed with the game. Anything beyond the hard difficulty obviously isn't going to be forgiving at all. Now that we're done with that, how about that Rise of the Samurai expansion? It's fairly horrible due to the same diplomacy issues, less unit types, slower gameplay due to each province needing to be converted to a specific allegiance, less building types, less potential money made per turn, etc. Buyers beware of the RoTS expansion.

To end this review I want to reiterate that the Fall of the Samurai expansion is truly excellent. Most of the diplomacy issues are fixed in this expansion, there are even more unit types, a longer overall campaign in regards to available turns, siege units  matter now, a similar skill tree but with a nice twist and better economic opportunities that make it feel very different from the standard skill tree, more provinces, design changes to the overall map of Japan, etc. Personally I prefer the feudal units in the standard campaign to the more modern units in the FoTS expansion but there's still so much to enjoy here.

What else can I say? Great game, but it has its faults.

reviewText:
The epitome of a good Total War game. Though I received this game a year after it was released, I feel no regrets in purchasing this game. Shogun 2 is the perfect game for beginners to get a grasp of what the series is like and its now become one of the classics for Total war veterans. Nothing feels more amazing than leading an army of samurai in Japans warring states period: The Sengoku Jidai. In this game, the mix of turn based strategy (with economic, political, and diplomatic ramifications) and real time battles is wonderful but the need to balance timing and aggression is more important than ever. The AI may seem difficult at first and hard to deal with but the Total War series has always been about realism and the AI's scripted actions make logical and historical sense.
Graphically Shogun 2 is stunning and one of the more easily run games in the series. It is a testament of Creative Assembly's hard work.
If you end up playing Shogun 2, I would also recommend playing its two expansions as well: Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai. Both expansions add more depth to the title while adding various new units and factions to play as.
My final word is Shogun 2 is the perfect game for history buffs and action fans alike who love leading massive armies into battle but also love using passive or aggressive diplomacy in the campaign as well.

reviewText:
Total War: Shogun 2 is an outstanding achievement, certainly worth the price you'll pay. It may be just focused on Japan and there's no cultural diversity etc. But that means that CA have been able to pay a lot of attention to detail and when it comes to detail there's a lot of it in Shogun 2.
The battles are amazing, all the animations and effects are really immersing and will have you playing for hours. Along with the campaign, which is great fun. The multiplayer is a massive improvement, there's coop campaign and avatar conquest; which is where you create your own general and army, and battle other players either in custom battles or for territories in Japan.

If you're a Total War fan don't hesitate in getting this game, the same can be said to anyone else who is interested in a good strategy game.

reviewText:
Firstly id like to say that Shogun 2 is not a bad game. No this is just my opinion that i feel the game is just not with my expections.

The graphics as anyone can say are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic and if someone said they are not they are foolish. The amazing graphics as always in Total War games have pushed systems to the edgy, something i love.

So what do i dislike? just about everything else. Everything you know and love is in this game and even improved such as the battles, support units and even the cities are refined. Yet the factions are boring with not much variation between them and all share pretty much the same tactic. Good but soon wore off. This is a complication mainly because of the setting and not much can be done about it.

I disliked the fact the devs focused so much on the online aspect. It has washed out the rest of the game. The Rock, paper, scisors aspect has been taken too litiral, games are now very predictable.

So its a good game, just not for me.
Sorry to all fans :( 8/10

reviewText: Honestly, this game is AMAZING! I personally think it is among, if not the best game from the Total War franchise. As a RTS and turn-based strategy game, it lives up to all that and much more. Unit, structural and environromental details leave nothing to the imagination; however, the campaign cinematics are humble despite the game having perfectly rendered in-game clips. Overall audio and visuals are breathe-taking (comparable to much newer AAA games). Don't be fooled, this game can still give your PC a run for its money especially on ultra settings with multiple AI's in the mix. I strongly recommend getting this game in a bundle with the standalone expansion (Fall of The Samurai) and the other existing DLCs. It is also VERY replayable and will always be great value for your money. If you don't already own this game and you like RTS and Japanese feudal lords, it's time to commit seppuku.

reviewText:
Ein starker Singleplayer mit großem Wiederspielwert und ein Multiplayer mit fabelhaften strategischen Möglichkeiten und Individualisierungspielraum auf der einen Seite. Balancingprobleme, eine hohe Hürde für Neueinsteiger und eine kaum zählbare Menge von Bugs auf der anderen.
Wer sich mühevoll in das Spiel einarbeitet und über gelegentliche Problemchen hinwegsehen kann, wird mit vielen Spielstunden voller Spaß in einem der besten Strategiespiele, die es aktuell für den PC gibt, belohnt.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A great singleplayer with high replay value and a multiplayer with phenomenal strategic possibilities as well as space for individualization on the one hand.
Balancing problems, a high hurdle to overcome for beginners and a huge amount of bugs on the other hand.
The ones who take their time to become acquainted with the game and overlook occasional problems get rewarded with many hours of entertainment in one of the best RTS games on the market.

reviewText:
Well, I had my first experience with the Total War franchise in Shogun 2.
I bought and played all DLC's, played both the online avatar conquest and coop campaing (only once, because it is practically dead now).
All the singleplayer campaings are awesome and the playability is really good.
All campaings will give you large amount of play time even playing on short campaing (I only played on long, but I can tell that even the short one is at least 30-50 hours of gameplay), but the first campaing, Shogun 2, and the Shogun 2 - Fall of the Samurai were my favorites due to the style of gameplay and technology already available, since the campaing Rise of the Samurai is supposed to be set before both, and they diverge in the gameplay because you don't actually need to capture the settlement to make it yours in the Rise of the Samurais (the allegiance system). What I was more excited about was the historical battles you get to fight, really amazing how they made that so every ramdom battle turns out to feel like you were reviving the Japanese's past fights (at least for me).
My only complaining is about the multiplayer, it is true, I didn't play much of the avatar conquest, but from what I played (2-3 hours) it was a real ♥♥♥♥, and the coop campaing could be really awesome, but as I said, it is dead now...

Summary, if you are a fan of Samurais and Japan history.. buy the game for sure! Just don't expect multiplayer...

reviewText:
This is an excellent game set in the Sengoku Jidai period of Japan. For me, the campaign proved to be challenging but not tedious. I recommend this to wargamers.
This game is more balanced as the effects of spear, cavalry, and sword units are more obvious than other games in the Total War series. You will have access to the same base of units as your enemy, but its not really a bad thing as there are enough nuances to each faction. Likewise, a bone-headed cavalry rush into a spear unit will skewer cavalry with confidence, though with no certainty. Likewise, spear units will die at the hands of sword units, and so on. The key in winning therefore is knowing what unit to commit in an action. A reserve is helpful in exploiting gaps in enemy lines or plugging holes in your own.
The game is not without its faults; the chief complaint I have is that the AI loves to spawn little armies that wreck a little havok in your lands but offer little challenge in a pitched battle. The campaign AI is worse as its diplomacy is still vague. Strangely, though the AI offers a good challenge in hard or higher setting, its predictability in patterns of attack and consolidation of its forces cheapens my sense of accomplishment. It would have added a little flavor and attention to detail if an enemy general with a supposed penchance for cavalry rush do so rush me its cavalry reserve as a coup de main. The enemy agents are OK and add a little unknown factor that adds immersion into the game. But I digress...
This game is best enjoyed with your friends. A match with friends or even strangers will give you that added flavor and quirks that make you come back for more. The Shogun 2 community is good, and often welcoming to new players willing to listen to veteran gamers.
Long story short, what you find lacking in the singleplayer campaign you will get in the multiplayer.

reviewText:
Shogun 2, my personal favorite Total War game, and probably one of the best titles ever published by CA, along Medieval 2 and Rome 1.

The game is absolutely fantastic. No more. There are flaws, but the game gets almost all aspects that made the Total War series into what it is and executes them in an almost perfect harmony. You start controlling a Daimyo in the Sengoku Jidai era of Feudal Japan and is up to you to make your way trough rivals, missionaries, rebellions and even the Shogun itself to bexome the Supreme ruler of Japan.

Now why is this game so good?

Because it is the epitome of polish, everything seems to flow naturally, like the stream of a river. The strategic map is very well done, it creates chokepoints and natural obstacles so you will nedd to fight certain enemies to control vital regions, which also makes for excellent defensive positions to hold. There are three types of agents( actually 5 if you include Geisha and the portuguese Missionary), and their rock-paper-scissor way of interacting is perfect. The Ninja is perfect for infiltration, sabotage and assassination, and excels at eliminating Monks. Beware of the Metsuke, they may buy off your Generals, kill Ninjas and bribe settlements. The Monk may seem harmless at first, but leave one alone and you may have a full rebellion deep inside your territory, and that can be your downfall.

Unfortunatelly not everything is perfect, as the map design tends to promote siege battles regularly, and sometimes agents fail much more than they succeed. Fortunatelly, having a level 6 agent means you have a BIG advantage over your opponents( level 6 ninja and their generals will fall one after the another like maple leaves on Autumn).

Now the battles.... What can I say regarding them that anybody else hasn't said better than I? I can only say that even after 900 hours of gameplay  leading your Samurai while they charge shouting 'Banzai' still gives me goose bumps. Units are very disciplined and will often fight to the death of you have a powerful general and high morale, which enables Epic Last Stand situations. Siege Battles may become tiresome, but are very good nonetheless, because they are sometimes quite challenging, for example, try taking Kyoto without Two full-stack armies to see what happens, specially at hard at very hard.

There sooooo many things to talk about this game, but if you want to know what I'm talking about, simply play and you'll see.All things considered, BUY this game.

This game is a glorious victory my lord!"

reviewText:
Total War: Shogun 2 is an outstanding achievement, certainly worth the price you'll pay. It may be just focused on Japan and there's no cultural diversity etc. But that means that CA have been able to pay a lot of attention to detail and when it comes to detail there's a lot of it in Shogun 2.
The battles are amazing, all the animations and effects are really immersing and will have you playing for hours. Along with the campaign, which is great fun. The multiplayer is a massive improvement, there's coop campaign and avatar conquest; which is where you create your own general and army, and battle other players either in custom battles or for territories in Japan.

If you're a Total War fan don't hesitate in getting this game, the same can be said to anyone else who is interested in a good strategy game.

reviewText:
Total War is a series that has intrigued me, but frightened me off just the same. The difficulty in learning what unit does what, and how each operate was a very difficult task, but learning to overcome that uncertainty pushed Shogun 2 into a limelight that it's easier predecessor (Empire) held.

Shogun 2 provides a mixture of well-designed characters with extremely detailed animations into deadly historical war. In true Total War fashion, just having superior numbers and zerging" an enemy unit does not always win. It's the proper use of the right "tool" to do the job that prevails here.

It does take a LOT to get used to
date: and it takes awhile to get into the "swing" of things
recommended: but give it enough time and you will be stroking your chin in thought as you effectively play your real-time chess against an opponent that already knows your army better than you do."

reviewText:
First off I love the Total War series.  These games are exceptional to say the least.  SHOGUN 2 is probably my favorite out of the franchise thus far.  The ease of map and town navigation make the game simple to jump into if you've played any of the previous Total War games.  If you haven't, the overwhelmingly helpfull advisors" will get you through the early stages of the game rather quickly and efficiently.

What's good:
- Graphics are smooth and quite detailed even when you zoom way in on units
- Map control is crisp and easy to manage
- Naval battles are easy to get a handle on after a few battles
- The technology trees are easy to understand and plan out
- It's easy to jump right in and play

What's not so good:
- Understanding what each building does or chains to easily (it took me a few games to get it right)
- Not knowing what building to make keeps you from getting the right units as early as you can in the game.
- The time table to win the short campain is VERY challenging
- Takeda clan never wants to trade with me....... WTH Takeda!?!?!
- There always seems to be SOMETHING that makes your Dynamo dishonorable

reviewText:
Hirashai! Hirashai! Come! Take a seat and hear me fellow Samurai!
Yea.... kinda over the top opening line.. But! Back to the topic!
I was always intrigued about Asian warfare,especially Japan and its samurai.
Total War:SHOGUN 2 was the game that came before ROME 2 to the TW series known for their turn based campaign and real time-chess like battles.
Shogun 2 is set durning 3 crusial time periods of Japan's history (well,one if you don't buy the DLCs...):1) Sengoku Jidai (The age of the warring states) set at 1545 when most of Japan's notorious warlords were already alive and active.
2)The Gempei war,set at 1175. This war is what caused the Shogun to be the main ruler of Japan and what made the empror who ruled until then a figurehead.
3)The Boshin war,set at 1865,During this war,Japan yet again fought itself to change the regime,this time the empror wins. This war also marks Japan's massive modernazetion which will lead her to be a superpower eventually,but not all are happy with this and some tradition-loving Samurai will revolt and try to take matters into their own hands (Sheesh... sounds like Mea Shearim on an asian grand scale...)
Now enough with history lesson! (if you wanna know more just go to wikipedia or somthin'... thats what I did... and somehow got hooked on anime in the prosess...) Lets talk about the game!

Gameplay
Even for an unexpirienced player to the series (which I was when I bought it) learning the controls is easy as they give you a well directed tutorial on every aspect of the game.
The AI might be a bit annoying (waiting on the highest hill,setting tax rate on extreme and not getting any rebellions,betray you when you can clearly crush their arses,etc) but it is still quite well made,still,if they grind your gears,there are many wonderful mods on the community's site: twcenter.net which change gameplay for the better (some are even setting the game on different timeframes if you ever get bored with the main campaigns).

Graphics
From my limited japanese: kire desu! Or,the game is looking f***ing beautiful! (well if your computer can run it on med-high settings and up... I seriously upgraded my rig just so I can see those tiny asians kill each other without the game moving slow! But thats just me,and if you'll know me,you will see I'm bloody wierd!).
Graphics look amazing! both on the battlefield and the campaign map. If you close up durning a battle, you will see samurai and ashigaru fighting to the death,on the campaign map you can see clouds around mount Fuji,seagulls flying above ports and your generals (who used all their movement points) sitting on a stool with your clans flag in hand and relaxing (or taking a crap,they do sit like they are...). If you zoom on a unit that's been hit by a volly of arrows (considering they are not naginata or bulletproof samurais) you will see that some men will instantly die with 2-3 arrows stuck in them while some others will roll around in pain with the arrow stuck in their body (I'm pretty sure an arrow to the knee won't kill you instatly... we have the guards from Skyrim to justify this!). There is much to say about the graphics but its better for you to see everything yourselves,after all,a picture is worth a thousand words!

Sound
The game sounds wonderful! When on the campaign map,a calm tune will be herd,changing from turn to turn to have the feeling of the season's changing. A tentious music will be herd during a realtime battle,until the two armies clash and the tune will become glorified and brutal to mark the horrors and beauty of war at the same time.
As for the voices,in Japanese they sound amazing,the commander of the unit will respond to every command you give them as they should (they will shout kogeki!" when you order them to attack and "zenshin!" when ordered to advance
date: I ain't gonna explain to ya what his words mean! use your logic
recommended: or google translate if you are in dire situation!)
hoursPlayed: that massive "hai!" a unit shouts after the commander always makes me smile.\nOn the campaign map

reviewText:
Ive played all of the Total War games, and I have to say this is my favorite one. Japan is, of course, not as big as some of the other places Total War games take place in (see Rome 2 huge map) but it doesnt feel small, and the relationships with other clans in the campaign map can make or break you, also there is a wild card called Kyoto that can crush you early on if you make them mad, and eventually you can capture it. The fighting is also very interesting, and I would actually recommend the blood DLC because sometimes you will want to zoom in on the 1v1s the unit AI automatically go to, put on the slow motion mode, and watch a display of skill samurai versus samurai, or a charge of ashigaru and see people get impaled and lifted off their feet. Unlike the other Total War games, this one doesnt have sheilds. You may have mixed feelings about this, but ultimately it just means ranged is more effective and strategy for this game must usually be done differently. The maps have a lot of terrain you can take advantage of, so that's a plus that replaces sheilds if used correctly. If you are not a fan of the artillery in other Total War games, there is very little of it used in this game, unless you get FotS because then you pretty much bought a game based on gunpowder.

The multiplayer is more fun than the traditional; choose units, fight. In Shogun 2 you pick your army, after some time playing, from veterans that you have leveled up, that have their own skill branch and that you can specialize to fit specific needs and change the color of their uniforms (my entire army is pink), including your avater (general (mine is pink)) who can specialize in swordsmanship, bows, or just being a commander. There are also buffs and debuffs, and more units you can gain and use in multiplayer through a small slightly interactable map of Japan. This kind of multiplayer certainly isnt for people who hate investing time or getting slightly wrecked at lower levels because the veteran system/buffs allows higher ranking or people who have spent more time to have a large amount of veterans. You may also be discouraged by the FotS players if you play the traditional style Japanese units, which I do. I learned just to suck it up and adapt my tactics.

I find it hard to say bad things about this game, and it is probably for you if you like other Total War games.

reviewText:
To be frank this game is simply amazing. I will split the following review into three parts starting with G, graphics, gameplay and godly awesome animations.

Graphics.
This game is simply beautiful. The highly detailed distance scaling units and landscape add so much to the game visually. It looks very fitting into the time period of which it is set. Other details such as falling cherry blossom flowers on the battlefield make the game's atmosphere very appealing and genuine. Although the rediculous blood effects may turn you to believe it is bad exagguration, it honestly reminds you of good samurai movies with similar effects. These small details make the game so much more fantastic.

Gameplay.
Total War: SHOGUN 2 has an easy to understand food chain" of units.
Spear beats cavalry
recommended: bows beat swords and swords beat spears.\nThis is the core of the game
hoursPlayed: however other units are thrown in as well to make it more exciting. These include matchlock units
voteText: which are basically short range gun units effective at murdering everything on the battlefield. You might think at first these are overpowered
helpfulPercent: but just like everything else in the game it has a weakness. Other missile units because of it's low range.\nAnother example are kisho units such as ninjas who can hide on the battlefield while moving slowly or sitting idle. These units are usually weak to cavalry and missiles
votesHelpful: so they are best at engaging melee infantry units from the flanks using their special abilities such as grenades.\n\nRetainer cards are special
votesTotal: well.... cards
votesFunny: that you can choose a limited number of to play for a battle. These retainer cards can give bonuses to your units such as +2 melee attack to all sword infantry or hinder your opponent's army with cards such as -10 ammunition for enemy bow units.\n\nThe main multiplayer mode is called avatar conquest
commentsCount: where you create your own general and build his skills and army using veteran units
column16: which are experienced soldiers that you can upgrade and keep in your reserve. In avatar conquest you are given a map of Japan on which you move your general across to capture provences. Each time you win a multiplayer battle you will unlock the provence you are currently standing on
column17:
which may reward you with a new specific unit or retainer card.

Finally we have god damn animations.
The animations in this game are fantastic. Using motion capture technologies Creative Assembly was able to create some of the most beautiful animations I have seen in a video game. From decapitations to complete entry and exit of a weapon through a man's chest
column18: these animations happen in 1 vs 1 duels in the middle of a battlefield surrounded by other units who are also doing the same. The clipping in this game is barely noticable unless you are really looking in a high clipping scenario such as when a unit of yours moves through another unit of yours. The detail of the animations are fantastic and inserted EVERYWHERE. Interestingly there are highly detailed animations for men climbing walls
column19: throwing flaming kindling and even firing and reloading seige weapons. Simply well done Creative Assembly
column20: if I wore hats I would take mine off.\n\nSo
column21: well done on reading this entire review. What are you doing? Honestly? Get out there and murder some fools!"

reviewText:
Shogun 2 is one of the best games I've personally ever played. Being a newcomer to the Total War franchise, I didn't expect this game to blow my socks off.

The Good:
-aggressive Campaign AI
-Great cinematic cutscenes
-Gorgeous graphics that hold up even in 2016
-Impressive combat animations
-Massive Battles
-interesting multiplayer concept
-Long and fun campaign
-Drop-in campaign battle system
-The Japanese style and art of the game
The Bad:
-Sometimes questionable battle AI
-Advisors talk even when advice is set to none for me
-Steep learning curve for new players in the multiplayer in 2015-16 and above
-OP Bow units!

reviewText:
This game is a perfect example of a total war game done right. The game feels very polished wether that be the sleak graphics in battle, agent videos, or the neat menus and tabs on the campaign map,  everything comes together very nicely. Unlike most previous games in the series, the campaign ai is aggressive and can easily end your campaign prematurely if you make to many enemies or neglect diplomacy which is a welcome change.

Diplomacy has been improved greatly with the campaign ai generally making sensible decisions( e.g. they will usually accept any terms when close to being destroyed, allies will often offer money to assist them in wars, or offer to assist you in wars in exchange for helping them in their own)Allies  are easily the most reliable in the series and will normally not backstab you unless you are allied with a trechorous clan, have become weak and failed to maintain good relations, or triggered realm divide(more on this later) , and have even occasionally send troops to help you in battles which is a refresing change.

The co-op or versus campaigns(when no connection issues are present) are a complete blast, cordinating attacks with your friends and building your empires together is satisfying and a very enjoyable experience. While it is unrealistic that you will both have armies in every battle, it is possible to give friends in the campaign units under your control in both the campaign, and on the battlefield allowing participation in eachothers battles, regardless of faction and distance from one another.

Now that we have spoken about what is good about the game, I will now discuss the main problems, the battlefield ai is hit and miss. Sometimes the ai catches you by surprise  with clever use of flanking, or whittling you down with massed archers when it has missle superiorty, on the flip side the ai is prone to getting careless with it's generals, or playing far to passively on defense allowing players to take the initiave. It's most noticablely bad in sieges, where it often deploys it's troops akwardly allowing them to be dealt with easily( e.g. leaving it's archers completely undefended) and will climb the walls every time, even if a gate to the castle is wide open, causing their troops to take uneccessary casualties and morale loss. Unfortunatly though bad ai is nothing new to the total war series and  may stay this way for quite some time, however if this concerns you you may opt to allow a random player to take control of the ai armies on the campaign map to offer a (usually)greater challenge.

A lot of people are uhappy about the lack of variety in the clans, while each one has it's own unique specialty, and often gets a more powerful and cheaper, variant of a certain unit type, they do all use the same units(dlcs add some unique units to each faction, as well as one or two factions with many different units) although personally this doesn't bother me to much as playing to the factions specialty allows each clan to play differently offering a unique playthrough each campaign.

Finally one of the biggest issues in shogun 2 is realm devide, this mechanic happens late in the game when you take enough provinces. This causes the shogun to fear your power and declare you a enemy of the state, the result is diplomacy is thrown out the window, and inevitably all factions will declare war on you, including your allies. This mechanic is not implemted well and can often feel unfair, although mods can change the way realm devide works allowing you to easily keep your allies and friends after realm devide allowing for a much more enjoyable experience.


Some people may feel intimited by the setting of the game or the flaws that i have outlined, but i can't stress enough that this game is a easily among the top total war games in the series, and in my opinion is vastly superior to it's successor rome 2. There are ways to deal with most of the games flaws which i have outlined above allowing you to take full advantage of the many great features CA nailed when making this game.

Wether you are a total war fan that has not purchased shogun 2, or someone who is interested in the franchise or strategy games in general, i can't recommend this game enough.

TL:DR The game is polished and has some of the best diplomacy/battles in the series, multiplayer is fun and addictive while it does have some issues(siege ai/realm devide and a lack of variety) it's in my opinion well worth the price.

reviewText: Honestly, this game is AMAZING! I personally think it is among, if not the best game from the Total War franchise. As a RTS and turn-based strategy game, it lives up to all that and much more. Unit, structural and environromental details leave nothing to the imagination; however, the campaign cinematics are humble despite the game having perfectly rendered in-game clips. Overall audio and visuals are breathe-taking (comparable to much newer AAA games). Don't be fooled, this game can still give your PC a run for its money especially on ultra settings with multiple AI's in the mix. I strongly recommend getting this game in a bundle with the standalone expansion (Fall of The Samurai) and the other existing DLCs. It is also VERY replayable and will always be great value for your money. If you don't already own this game and you like RTS and Japanese feudal lords, it's time to commit seppuku.

reviewText:
Firstly id like to say that Shogun 2 is not a bad game. No this is just my opinion that i feel the game is just not with my expections.

The graphics as anyone can say are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic and if someone said they are not they are foolish. The amazing graphics as always in Total War games have pushed systems to the edgy, something i love.

So what do i dislike? just about everything else. Everything you know and love is in this game and even improved such as the battles, support units and even the cities are refined. Yet the factions are boring with not much variation between them and all share pretty much the same tactic. Good but soon wore off. This is a complication mainly because of the setting and not much can be done about it.

I disliked the fact the devs focused so much on the online aspect. It has washed out the rest of the game. The Rock, paper, scisors aspect has been taken too litiral, games are now very predictable.

So its a good game, just not for me.
Sorry to all fans :( 8/10

reviewText:
Best Total War Game 10/10

+ Huge epic battles, fight over Japans beautiful landscape - and most importantly, the Shoguns Palace!
+ All playable factions really do have a massive amount of diversity, every game different from the next
+ DLC's FoTS and RoTS are 100% worth paying for
+ Beginnings of a new kind of warfare - New gunpowder units, brought by western traders!
+ Faction DLC's - i couldnt have picked better clans myself!
+ Best battles ever seen in a Total War Game
+ Really does set the atmosphere for 'The age of the country at war' , or the Sengoku Jidai

- Family doesnt really matter - lose your faction leader, and just be replaced with an infinite supply of brothers in law's
- Espionage could be a little better
- Naval combat in stock game is slow, id rather auto - resolve (but it still looks great!)
- Enemy gets a little confused in Seige battles - never brings heavy weapons and kills himself climbing the walls
- Avatar Mode is the WORST thing ive ever seen - pits new players vs. max rank enemies or DLC factions.

and that'll be me.

reviewText:
ForewordsI think everyone (who plays such) has their own favourite Total War -game, it is still quite unfair to compare each others because, they all have their bad sides... even the fabled Medieval 2 or original Rome. I have to say, that original Rome was my personal favourite for a long time... because I was so damn good in it. I also hated Medieval 2, because its diplomacy made no sense (to me) and I got my bottom rammed every time I tried it. So... Shogun 2?

OverviewTotal War: Shogun 2 is strategy game, mixing turn-based strategy, economy and army movements in campaign map, and real-time strategy in battles.
In campaign map you control and move your troops around the map, improve cities with new buildings or upgrading old ones and of course making diplomatic decisions for or against your enemies. In my oppinion, the campaign map is where you actually play the game and you can, if you want to, skip all battles by using autofight" option. Focussing only in the campaign map and its varieties will take
recommended: a great deal of time and demands that you actually think what you want to do and how and by what expenses. Luckily
hoursPlayed: the game has inbuild wiki/guide that helps in most of your question.\nIn battles you control your armies of sometimes thousands of troops and
voteText: hopefully
helpfulPercent: win. Game has fair amount of different troop types that support each others. Your job is to forge an army that conquers any foe and you feel good to battle with.\n\nCons*If you've ever played any Total War
votesHelpful: you know how this works. And yes
votesTotal: that is a bad thing. Even if they have come a long way in 11 years from Shogun to Shogun 2
votesFunny: it is still Total War.\n*The Shogun 2's diplomacy
commentsCount: however
column16: is quite frustrating and a mod to fix it is highly recommended. You can make vassal states
column17: you can forge strong relations by marriage and all other sort of stuff
column20: everyone starts to hate you. Everyone. Even that family
column21: who has traded three daughters for your leader's sons and vice versa. When the "Realm Divide" triggers
column22: all other factions declare war on you and if not well prepared... you will get your ♥♥♥♥ rammed.\n*I'm not really sure

reviewText:
I've played all of the Total War games except for Rome II - the Original Medieval: Total War and Warhammer: 40,000 series are what pushed me even deeper down the rabbit hole of real-time strategy games.

If you like the Japanese Samurai setting, real-time strategy, grand strategy, and being a powerful general/shogun, then you will love this game.

The aesthetics are fantastic - the detail in your units during battles is very well-done. The different ship models are also great during sea battles. The music and sounds add to the atmosphere and are very good as well.

The controls are not too difficult to grasp and the in-game tutorial/advisor is very helpful in orienting new players to the game/series. The learning curve is moderate to difficult - especially if you are not familiar with the Total War series (or RTS-games in general).

Gameplay occurs in two-fold: first, you move your armies around in the main map and build your structures/defenses. After that turn phase, if any battles need to resolve, you will go into the battle screen (unless you decide to autoresolve). Here, you can deploy your units and then begin combat when you are ready. Night battles are very fun, and sieges are awesome to watch if you field a large number of archers and/or siege weapons. You can storm castles by scaling the walls as well.

Diplomacy in this game is fleshed-out very well - your reputation will affect how other leaders respond to you (have a history of betraying your allies and other leaders will be more hesitant to enter negotations with you). Establishing trade agreements with your neighbors can help increase their disposition towards you.

The special units like the spy or general (increases army training while in the field) are very useful, and you can level up most units and pick skills for them. The research tree is essential to ensuring that you are on an even playing field with your opponents technologically - fall too behind and they will not only field larger armies, but also have them outfitted with more superior equipment.

The game (and series) is an absolutely amazing staple of the RTS-genre and you must give it a try if you are interested at all.

Highly recommend!

reviewText:
After the marketing disaster of Empire, and the slight comeback from Napoleon, will Shogun manage to bring back the CA reputation?

I can proudly say; YES, IT DID! I CAN'T EXPLAIN HOW HAPPY I AM THAT CA FINALLY GOT IT RIGHT AGAIN! So, let's step off my joy and get down to brass tacks. First off, the good.
The setting was a home run for CA, finally bringing back the Samurai origins of the original Total War: Shogun. Take control of various Clans across Japan in the Sengoku-jidai, to claim the title of supreme Shogun, military leader of all of Japan. The thing that is crucial for this is the campaign map, which is easy to learn how to use and the new graphics set by the game are stunning.

The battle AI still needs some improvement, but it is far better than Napoleon, and let's not mention Empire. I can actually have a hard time battling an army outnumbered 3 to 1, but it is easy to win if you have the altidude advantage. Shogun 2 brings back tactical thinking and how to respond to real charges, rather than just line infantry warfare from Empire and Napoleon.

As of me, I am Takeda Shingen, Daimyo of the Takeda clan. I proved history wrong by denying the Oda of their title as Shogun, and had created numerous triumphs in the Kyushu peninsula, as well as reclaiming the Imperial Capital, Kyoto, for myself. The Uesugi scourge is no longer a threat, as i had slain Uesugi Kenshin in the grandest battle.

The thing i love about the total war Series, and I mentioned this in my Napoleon walkthrough is that the Immersion is something that CA always gets right. I was actually feeling like a 16th century Japanese Warlord while charging my Katana cavalry straight into the enemy General.

And not to mention, the agent feature is new and improved. Gaishas? Ninjas? HELL YEAH! There isn't a better feelign than to killing an enemy general in his sleep, or killing 3 japanese generals while posing as a sultry maiden of the night. Let's not mention the rest.

The bad is almost not there; I had no problems while playing my Takeda campaign. It was smooth, immersive, and most of all, fun. This is what i had been waiting for for 4 years, and i'm really glad CA finally delivered. It's a shame that they gave most of the attention to this, not the even more anticipated Rome II. *sigh*. But I digress, let us go to the final verdict.

Final Verdict: 9.5 out of 10. You guys might wonder why i gave it a 9.5 and not a 10, because of how I boasted it, but it still doesn't achieve the perfection that was Rome. I know that this might sound biased, but I am serious. This game is the pinnacle of CA comebacks, but the same can't be said for Rome II.

Closing up, I have one final thing to say to you: GET THIS GAME NAO, NOT HAVING IT IS A DISHONOR FOR UR FAMIRY!

SHAMFUR DISPRAY!

reviewText:
Before I begin, I would just like to explain the reason I don't have much recorded time on this game is because I play offline. At the time I wrote this review, I must've invested a good 20-30 hours in this game already, only 9 days after recieving it.

The main problem I find with most Total Wars (Mainly the ones before Empire) is how complicated it can be, both in battle and the campaign map. Shogun 2 isn't very complicated at all, and it's quite simple and easy to play. You could say it's optimised for a Human's CPU lol. At the same time, the gameplay in both campaign and battle is epic. Despite all being in their same Japanese cultures, the clans have different units and advantages, without ruining the atmosphere of the game, and that, I'm pretty impressed with.

For example, the Otomo clan are great with matchlocks, whether it's recruiting them, or firing them; So this makes up for the fact the Otomo isn't well liked due to being Catholic. The Shimazu clan are well known for their mastery of melee combat; And for a simple player like me who relies more on the skill of their soldiers rather than their strategic minds, that's pretty awesome.

A tactic I commonly use is matchlocks at the front, bows behind the matchlocks, and infantry behind the bows (And obviously, heavy cavalry at the flanks). This way, both the bows and matchlocks can unleash devastation on the enemy, and when they get too close, I tell my matchlocks and bows to pull back and my infantry to charge. And obviously, if they try to flank me, I'll just run them down with the cavalry.

The campaign is pretty damn awesome too. Everything from the diplomacy, to the technological tree, to the city and army management, it's really well made in my opinion. Honour is also taken much more seriously in Japan as well. I wouldn't recommend sacking or razing cities, or any other dishonourable actions, no matter how raging you are because you were betrayed. The thing is, horrendous actions like that lowers your Daimyo's (Faction Leader) honour significantly, and this causes many problems, such as relations being strained with other clans, even if they're your allies. Your subjects and generals will take a disliking to you and become less loyal.

Shogun 2 has alright graphics, and runs pretty smoothly most of the time. But I suppose it all depends on what computer you have. Shogun 2 runs on pretty high settings smoothly enough for me though.

Aside from the gameplay, I really love the atmosphere of the game itself. The soundtrack reflecting the bloody and terrifying times of the sengoku jidai period in Japan. Especially during battles, the soundtrack gets a bit scary. It just makes you think about how terrified the soldiers must've been, because not all of them were samurai just wanting to die, a lot of them were just civilians levied into the army.

I love both Total War and Japanese history, that's why I love this game. If you love Total War and Japanese history, then I would definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
To review this game we must do so in isolation, ignoring complaints from Amazon reviews and many other areas that claim the excessive Steam download times are unbearable. It is of course frustrating to purchase a new game only to have to wait many, many hours for it to download, but we must accept that the era of disc based gaming is coming to a close and the more cost effective method of direct downloads from the net will dominate the coming decades of gaming. To clarify, I agree that waiting long download times SUCKS completely, but it would be ridiculous to pan a game based on such a development as many fans of the Total War series have seem to of done.

Now that aspect has been discussed, we can focus on the gameplay itself. This is a stripped down, back to basics Total War experience, doing away the global theatres of Empire: Total War and also the multiple trade continents that spanned the earth. This far more manageable, niche setting of Shogunate Japan provides an authentic, raw and beautifully brutal backdrop for the Total War series, enhancing the original Shogun instalment and roaring it into the modern era. The aesthetics of the game, the soundtrack, images and unit appearances, all feel genuine and carefully crafted. We truly feel part of the period.

Although Japan does not provide the largest of operating theatres for multiple warring factions, this adds to the relentless feel of warfare during this period, as you will be vying for provinces constantly changing hands, battling for strategic strong points. The politics of Empire have been done away with and trade simplified, many will point towards a sense of ‘dumbing down’, but I would argue the developers have changed the game effectively based on the period. Politics, trade theatres and revolution suits Renaissance colonies perfectly, yet by slightly simplifying this edition of Total War we are fully focused on the aspects that made gamers fall in love with the original games, warfare. Battles are large, numerous and chaotic, while the graphics and sounds are Total War at its atmospheric best.

As your clan develops (which it will through a streamlined technology tree) you will gain access to powerful units that feel powerful, that you can use effectively in battle. You will also have to choose between foreign temptations and domestic devotion, choosing to gain new weapons and religions from the West or choose to remain loyal to Japans heritage. Both options have their advantages and bring diversity to the gameplay and also provides an historically accurate backdrop. Options for choices such as these are not as numerous as we may like them to be, but they do at least convey the sense that we are head of a powerful clan.

Diplomacy is still far from perfect, however Shogun 2’s diplomacy has the fewest faults as opposed to previous instalments. Clans will still turn on you despite alliances and military access can be cancelled at a moments notice for no apparent reason. It would be a welcomed edition to include many more options in the diplomatic relations panel helping to add depth to the diplomatic process, which hopefully we will see in future editions of Total War.

Unit types are accurate yet they are not as diverse as previous games. Rome: Total War provided such a high standard of diverse unit type that every game since then has not quite matched it for its unit variety. Most clans have the exact same unit types with only skill bonuses based on clan type that fully distinguish them. Although this may be partly due to the time period, it means that replayability is not quite as enjoyable as many of the clans feel the same. That being said, many hours of gameplay are still available here, its only the miscellany of the hours that is an issue.

Sea battles are far more engaging than in Empire, yet withmedieval Japanese warships, the battles were always going to be limited in excitability. They don’t pack the punch that naval battles had in Empire, but they are easier to control and maintain which is an essential plus during large scale battles. They look fantastic however, becoming a staple of the Total War genre. Generals can now gain experience through such sea battles, allowing you to improve certain traits of your commanders  in a basic RPG element that works in tangent with the main game seamlessly.

Shogun 2 goes back to what made the original games fantastic. Fast, ferocious and tactical battles supplemented by strategic considerations in the theatre of war. This is Total War back to its brilliant best. There are still issues with the game of course, many of which can be altered and changed through a certain DarthMod, however the vanilla game is still extremely playable. I would fully recommend.

Where should the series go next? Empire 2? Ancient China? The Great War? What are your thoughts on Shogun 2 and Rome 2? Any comments are welcome whether you agreed or disagreed with my review. I’ll be sure to reply to all comments when I can. Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME

I made the mistake on holding off on this game for so long because (being a fan of Empire's style) I thought that feudal Japan felt like a boring distant culture I could not get into, let alone relate to, but after watching enough reviews with overwhelming praise for the game, I just had to give it a try...and I got sucked in.

Everything in this game is either perfect or darn near perfect.  From the music and voices to the artwork, this is a very immersive game.  Combat animations give the most fluid and interesting (and brutal) portrayals of combat I've ever seen in a Total War game (haven't played Rome 2 yet though)

The main tutorial teaches most of what you need to know, such as how to use the campaign map, the basics of attacking, but I would strongly recommend searching for and studying battle tips on youtube (and there are plenty!).  Just remember: Spear beats horse, sword beats spear, horse beats sword, bow beats everything at distance, and everything beats bow up close, and keep your general safe and close.  Naval combat is the game's only weakness, as early on it feels like its just archer platforms shooting eachother.  You'll be desperate to upgrade and get ships with cannons to spice it up.

Just don't do what I did on my nooby first try...expanding and recruiting too many too fast, running out of food and money, losing public order, and starting an early realm divide, A PERFECT NIGHTMARE  (It's actually pretty much common sense when governing the campaign map, so don't worry about stressful brainstorming on this)

All in all, this is a game every PC should have.  I'd recommend it to anyone who likes RTS games or would like to get into RTS games.  I also strongly recommend it to RTS fans who have been on the fence over getting this game.  It's worth every cent.  (Don't forget Fall of the Samurai though, some people say it's even better than plain Shogun 2)

reviewText:
How could you not want to raise an army of samurai and dominate japan?  It is a hybrid turn-based/RTS game.  While you are in the strategy map you must build and move armies, upgrade cities, manage family affairs, adjust tax rates, and open new trade routes in order to gain a strategic edge over your enemies and allies.  Once an army or navy engages another in combat it becomes a classic RTS game.  This game engine is CA's most stable, well-balanced engine out of the entire TW series.  If their Rome2 engine was even half as good as this one, then Rome2 wouldn't be such a piece of ♥♥♥♥.  Love this game, the campaign is fun and the multiplayer makes for a unique online experience.

- Graphics: 9/10
- Gameplay: 9/10
- Singleplayer(story): 9/10
- Multiplayer: 7/10

reviewText:
Most of the time strategy titles come in one of two flavors, real time or turn based, both which have their merits and draw backs, Shogun 2, like other games in the Total War series blends both into a solid and satisfying mix. From the campaign map you run your clan and make decisions regarding what is built in your lands, how much you tax those living under your rule, building your armies in a strategic Risk like manner, and in battles you have the chance to either auto-resolve or personally take command of the battle yourself, of the two options I highly recomend the latter.

The battles are large, epic and quite a sight to behold and the fact that you cant replenish troops mid battle means more focus on actual tactics rather than simple zerg rush style tactis. Plus there are few things more satisfying than overcoming a larger army through good strategy and tactics. The fact that you can zoom in for a close view of the clashes as they happen and the pre-battle speeches by your generals add to the feel and presentation of the real time battles and because of that it' all the more worth it to take control for yourself. Other things that add to it is your troops fatigue, the morale that is effected by the flow of the batle and the presence of the general and even weather condition that can help or hinder.

Things are slower on the campaign map of course, much like chess thats where more than anything you will be thinking and planning, with your armies and agents being represented like game pieces on the map which you can move from place to place. Expanding, and growing is something that cant be rushed, or else you will be crushed under the weight of a clan that simply cannot be supported, whether it's because the army is simply so large it costs too much to maintain, food shortages across the land, or just large scale public unrest, it's better to be methodical and take it slow, picking the right moves for the right time. Diplomacy between clans has features not seen in other games that add to your immersion. Your clan's daimyo (ie: you) is not some disembodied presence giving orders, but an actual unit that is a powerful general, not only is he represented but also his family tree, with sons that will one day become generals, and take his place when he dies, daughters which can be useful in forming diplomatic ties to other clans and various other relatives. Another thing to keep an eye on is our generals and their loyalty, a disloyal general can turn on you and tke his troop with him so keeping them loyal is a good idea.  Aside from that there are the standards like trade agreements and alliances.

Overall Shogun 2 is a must have for fans of the strategy genre.

reviewText:
I have never actually played strategy games before, or liked them (except Age of Empires II and a little Rome), but this game really sucked me in.

-Random lines, like: まだ風がありますよ！

reviewText:
I acquired this game because I wanted a Samurai: Total War game. It fulfills that requirement and more. The campaigns can be tough, especially since you seem to be beset by enemies, and you have a limited amount of time to fulfill your ambition of ruling Japan. This is especially true if you are at the far end of Honshu and need to march all the way to Kyoto to secure the Shogunate.

And that's just the base campaign. There is a Rise DLC which puts you in the same situation about 400 years before the base one. And then there is Fall, which adds a LOT of gunpowder weaponry and modern tactics, and deals with a short period that lead to the modernization of Japan (and indirectly to the Japanese Empire of WWII).

There is also a multiplayer game that can be fun, though challenging in a different way. As hard as the AI can be, other players are often craftier and less prone to being trampled underfoot by cavalry. And since those with Fall can use their weaponry it can sometimes lead to quality versus quantity matchups.

reviewText:
BUY THIS OR EMPIRE TW NOT ROME 2. ROME 2 IS BUGGED SH!T.

The Shogun 2 campaign is awesome and challenging on legendary difficulty. Battles are a lot of fun with good AI, nice fighting animations and overall balanced when it comes to units, spear against horses, bows to pick off advancing foes and swords against infantry etc. The General system was my favourite part with this game. reviewText:
Most of the time strategy titles come in one of two flavors, real time or turn based, both which have their merits and draw backs, Shogun 2, like other games in the Total War series blends both into a solid and satisfying mix. From the campaign map you run your clan and make decisions regarding what is built in your lands, how much you tax those living under your rule, building your armies in a strategic Risk like manner, and in battles you have the chance to either auto-resolve or personally take command of the battle yourself, of the two options I highly recomend the latter.

The battles are large, epic and quite a sight to behold and the fact that you cant replenish troops mid battle means more focus on actual tactics rather than simple zerg rush style tactis. Plus there are few things more satisfying than overcoming a larger army through good strategy and tactics. The fact that you can zoom in for a close view of the clashes as they happen and the pre-battle speeches by your generals add to the feel and presentation of the real time battles and because of that it' all the more worth it to take control for yourself. Other things that add to it is your troops fatigue, the morale that is effected by the flow of the batle and the presence of the general and even weather condition that can help or hinder.

Things are slower on the campaign map of course, much like chess thats where more than anything you will be thinking and planning, with your armies and agents being represented like game pieces on the map which you can move from place to place. Expanding, and growing is something that cant be rushed, or else you will be crushed under the weight of a clan that simply cannot be supported, whether it's because the army is simply so large it costs too much to maintain, food shortages across the land, or just large scale public unrest, it's better to be methodical and take it slow, picking the right moves for the right time. Diplomacy between clans has features not seen in other games that add to your immersion. Your clan's daimyo (ie: you) is not some disembodied presence giving orders, but an actual unit that is a powerful general, not only is he represented but also his family tree, with sons that will one day become generals, and take his place when he dies, daughters which can be useful in forming diplomatic ties to other clans and various other relatives. Another thing to keep an eye on is our generals and their loyalty, a disloyal general can turn on you and tke his troop with him so keeping them loyal is a good idea.  Aside from that there are the standards like trade agreements and alliances.

Overall Shogun 2 is a must have for fans of the strategy genre.
