reviewText:
Shogun 2 is a fun, fast paced and exciting game to say the least. The multiplayer is great, the campaign is great, the units are great and the varying factions are all great. Shogun 2 is the second version of the shogun series and one of the newer Total War games. It is unique in the use of its DLC to expand on the base game and features other great unique features that older Total War games lack. Now, although medieval Japan is not my variety historical period I loved the look of the game and got into lots of information about it before buying it finding it to be worth it. Sadly my system is not the best at running it but in playing it I've enjoyed it, especially the multiplayer for what I could run smoothly. With co-op systems, avatar general and army building combined with leaderboards that can be attributed to Steam groups the system is a great improvement to the Total War games before it. I personally stuck to the multiplayer for most of my playing period with the game unlike in previous games where I stuck to the single player nearly the whole time. Multiplayer alone would still make this game good. Unit choices are another really great aspect which works with the varying factions too. Their is even one on the president! I won't give you any clues on what its called though. The other great thing about the game not mentioned yet is the graphics. The general look of the game is great despite my poor specifications which shows that it is great beyond what I considered already good as higher specification computers will have an even better sight. To summarise the good points-

- Improved multiplayer
- Good DLC that works well improving on the base game
- Great graphics
- Interesting and varied number of units
- Unique and original factions
- Great Campaign
- Great Historical battles with huge clashes and great explanations to them

Now to the bad. The game is hard to run for me and since my system is alright I would say it may be an issue for some others out there. Lowering the quality of the game helps, but the single player can lose the nice look due to the game struggling. Also, from what I saw, the early mulitplayer battles are awful if you don't have riflemen as they are incredibly over-powered.  The DLC, although improving on what the game offers greatly is a bit unfair at times to those without it. Without DLC its hard to beat armies who have them and since most players have already got high in the rankings late entries may find the first ten to twenty matches a bit of a slaughter on them. I got some riflemen and soon found I was the one slaughtering others which became fun though, so it worked out! To summarise the bad points-

- Over-powered DLC at times
- Specification is slightly too high for some lower specified computers.

So the game is great despite its obsession with paying more on upgrades in and out of the game to make your experience more pleasing in combat I would easily score this game a 4/5, 8/10 or 80%. It shows Total War games to be improving in many aspects and is definetly a great strategy game overall.

reviewText:
Do you like Samurai?
Do you love HONORABLE fights?
Leading your Ashigari (common, foot soldiers) into Battle to Unite Japan. Under the Banner of your Clan, you fight for Honor and Glory!

9/10

The Grand Campaign is more or less about the BIG armies or SMALL at the beginning, fighting for supremacy over the Land.
The most focus is actual combat and RTS in the armies fighting, you can possibly win, with your Army in a Blitzkrieg tactic with just Ashigari troops alone. Or build up a strong army, having lots of up-keep costs.

The only downside for me, personally, is that it lacks the Family Managment, like in TW:Rome 1 - there you could build up an Family Dinasty. Here this is impossible you have no chance of having influence on making a strong Clan as it means to be a clan. You only Rule like an Absolute Ruler - there are no intrigues in your Clan or similar Stuff which makes Sengoku a game that has the features of what this game is lacking. On the other side, if you could combine Sengoku and Shogun 2 into one game - this would have been a Game that the world would love to see.

reviewText: So far TWShogun 2 has been crazy!  The level of detail they put into the minute details are a HUGE improvement from the TWRome, which is the only other game I've played in the series.  The agents are much more involved, and you can tailor each agent to the type of skills you would need from them.  For instance you can have one ninja that is used for assassinating, and another that is just used for sabotage, developing their individual skill trees in those areas.  The trading system took some getting use to from TWR, but it's so much more competitive now.  The Navy plays an important role in this game, as opposed to TWR where I primarily used them to transport men, and the occasional blockade mission.  I have a buddy who to my knowledge has never played a game like this, but he has recently got into Clash of Clans, and I definitely want him to try this out if he likes that, this is on a whole other level.  There's so much I can talk about, but I'll just say that if you liked TWR, you'll love this.

reviewText:
AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME

I made the mistake on holding off on this game for so long because (being a fan of Empire's style) I thought that feudal Japan felt like a boring distant culture I could not get into, let alone relate to, but after watching enough reviews with overwhelming praise for the game, I just had to give it a try...and I got sucked in.

Everything in this game is either perfect or darn near perfect.  From the music and voices to the artwork, this is a very immersive game.  Combat animations give the most fluid and interesting (and brutal) portrayals of combat I've ever seen in a Total War game (haven't played Rome 2 yet though)

The main tutorial teaches most of what you need to know, such as how to use the campaign map, the basics of attacking, but I would strongly recommend searching for and studying battle tips on youtube (and there are plenty!).  Just remember: Spear beats horse, sword beats spear, horse beats sword, bow beats everything at distance, and everything beats bow up close, and keep your general safe and close.  Naval combat is the game's only weakness, as early on it feels like its just archer platforms shooting eachother.  You'll be desperate to upgrade and get ships with cannons to spice it up.

Just don't do what I did on my nooby first try...expanding and recruiting too many too fast, running out of food and money, losing public order, and starting an early realm divide, A PERFECT NIGHTMARE  (It's actually pretty much common sense when governing the campaign map, so don't worry about stressful brainstorming on this)

All in all, this is a game every PC should have.  I'd recommend it to anyone who likes RTS games or would like to get into RTS games.  I also strongly recommend it to RTS fans who have been on the fence over getting this game.  It's worth every cent.  (Don't forget Fall of the Samurai though, some people say it's even better than plain Shogun 2)

reviewText:
How could you not want to raise an army of samurai and dominate japan?  It is a hybrid turn-based/RTS game.  While you are in the strategy map you must build and move armies, upgrade cities, manage family affairs, adjust tax rates, and open new trade routes in order to gain a strategic edge over your enemies and allies.  Once an army or navy engages another in combat it becomes a classic RTS game.  This game engine is CA's most stable, well-balanced engine out of the entire TW series.  If their Rome2 engine was even half as good as this one, then Rome2 wouldn't be such a piece of ♥♥♥♥.  Love this game, the campaign is fun and the multiplayer makes for a unique online experience.

- Graphics: 9/10
- Gameplay: 9/10
- Singleplayer(story): 9/10
- Multiplayer: 7/10

reviewText: Addictive, engaging, and absolutely stunning in its art direction and gameplay, Shogun II: Total War is a masterpiece in the Total War franchise that combined most pleasing aspects from previous Total War games without becoming tiresome. A player will always find oneself challenged by choice of sword or musket, lance or sabre, stone or cannon. Although the game is seperated by two seperate products, Shogun II" and "Shogun II Fall of the Samurai
date: it is impossible to enjoy the experience with solely one. The multiplayer mode Avatar Conquest" was a novel addition that added an RPG element to the franchise that makes the player feel more connected to one's avatar. Matchmaking is much improved as the server tries its best to pit you against the most competitive player at your level. All in all
recommended: a masterpiece by the Creative Assembly!"
hoursPlayed: December 17, 2013
voteText: true
votesHelpful: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A polished experience with attention to details and immersive gameplay. Shogun 2 is a serious upgrade to the Total War franchise and for sure the best iteration so far.

At first the Sengoku Jidai historical period might seem confusing, with lots of names and places true to the Japanese medieval setting, but after some time the essence of TW games surfaces as strong as ever. The campaigns might get long but never boring.

The art and design is impeccably well presented, and the music is top-notch, even if somewhat repetitive when playing long sessions. The graphics are good and adaptable to a wide range of PCs. The interface is clear and beautiful, and I never encountered a glitch or bug in 70+ hours of gameplay.

The new mechanic of Realm Divide brings freshness and challenge to the stalled and/or boring mid-to-endgame, and is a very welcome feature that will divide the weak and inconsistent from the true strategists. The AI is really not that smart, and makes very illogical decisions---many times downright stupid---when playing the lower difficulties. The best experience comes playing on Hard and above, and of course the light RPG-like multiplayer avatar system.

Shogun 2 can entertain you for hours. With high replayability and infinite options, no campaign is ever the same. All DLC is worth having.

If you liked previous Total War games, this is a must own. Highly recommended.

reviewText: The Total war series is one of the only games that I would say I follow 'loyally'. Epic scale, historical simulation, beautiful graphics, and even RPG elements for your generals; this game truly is a 'story engine'.\n\nMore in line with the feel of M2TW, as opposed to the minutae of Empire TW, what it lacks in scale and cultural differences it makes up for in immersion and strategic nuance. 10/10, and not a game to miss.

reviewText:
Do you like Samurai?
Do you love HONORABLE fights?
Leading your Ashigari (common, foot soldiers) into Battle to Unite Japan. Under the Banner of your Clan, you fight for Honor and Glory!

9/10

The Grand Campaign is more or less about the BIG armies or SMALL at the beginning, fighting for supremacy over the Land.
The most focus is actual combat and RTS in the armies fighting, you can possibly win, with your Army in a Blitzkrieg tactic with just Ashigari troops alone. Or build up a strong army, having lots of up-keep costs.

The only downside for me, personally, is that it lacks the Family Managment, like in TW:Rome 1 - there you could build up an Family Dinasty. Here this is impossible you have no chance of having influence on making a strong Clan as it means to be a clan. You only Rule like an Absolute Ruler - there are no intrigues in your Clan or similar Stuff which makes Sengoku a game that has the features of what this game is lacking. On the other side, if you could combine Sengoku and Shogun 2 into one game - this would have been a Game that the world would love to see.

reviewText:
A fantastic game. Although some aspects are lacking e.g. sieges being fairly basic when compared to previous total wars such as Rome or Medieval II, without mods a mediocre variety of units, this does work with the time frame as line infantry of the era did not really change between factions. The game is still immense fun to play and the campaign I have lost days and days in playing. The multiplayer experience is good/acceptable although I think that the major issue is simply not enough play FOTS online rather than flaws in the matchmaking system itself.

All in all a great game,

8/10 without mods

9/10 with mods

reviewText:
HOLY ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥♥ NIPPLES THIS GAME IS GOOD. I have played almost ALL the total war games and this is by FAR the best. You play one of the clans in japan and u must capture Kyoto and hold it to become the shogun.

Now to the best bit of the game. the battles. First of the battles look amazing on high setting and still look prettu darn good on medium. The anommations on the infantry are amazing as they where motion captured by people who could use swords. The interface is the best and very easy to use.

The campaign map is also very good and easy to use. I found it very hard to find out how to build units and buildings in ther earlier games but in Shogun 2 it is so simple. You select the city u want to build something in. You go to the tab you want and u select the building or unit you want.

In summary this game is ♥♥♥♥ing epic and a must buy for all total war fans. One thing i must say is you need a quite good pc to run this game on mediuem to high settings and my old pc still struggled on low so make sure u can run the game before u buy it

reviewText:
This is an awesome game. However, here are some tips to give you the full experience:

Get good sound system, preferably head phones, with great bass and depth. I swear I can feel an earthquake whenever I start a three thousand man charge and my enemy initiates a charge of the same scale.

1080p is not bad, but I imagine a 4k monitor would be so much more noticable on a game like this compared to a FPS or RPG. Frankly, this is one of the few games where a 16k monitor would be worth the investment. Obviously, this is expensive and not necessary, I'm just making the point that in a battle involving 14000 men, it would be nice to see the whole battlefield

The AI is both incredibly smart and very stupid at the same time. For instance, during naval battles, if I was severely outmanned, I could play ring around the rosey around an island and watch their ships get caught on the island, where I can pick off the single ship that managed to keep up with me. On the other hand, and this really amazed me, the AI reciprocated this tactic against me. I had attacked an enemy fleet with brute force as I had an equal or superior fleet, and I set ablaze or otherwise forced surrender of all but one enemy ship. This ship then literally kited ME and very nearly picked off 2 or 3 of my ships. All the while, I was chasing him expecting him to make some stupid illogical AI mistake, and it never came. I noticed he was circling and it seemed he was not about to make a mistake, so I sent a ship infront of his path. They collided and he lost all his momentum, and then I was able to box him in and finally kill him.

The large scale land AI seems to be fine and doesn't act very different than I would. They tend to put archers on hills, and even try to redirect my melee force and make pockets where calvary is to be sent in to crush my archers. However, they tend to be impatient if they are on the offensive and put themselves in chokes that I've set up with the land around my armies. I don't suppose there was any way around that though, that was the only way to get to me and as my archers were at higher elevation he couldn't pick me off with his archers

Small scale AI, as in a unit by unit basis, could have room for upgrading.

My final thought: Great game to have and experience. Brings strategy to a whole new level

reviewText:
Действие игры происходит на трех из четырех крупнейших японских островов: Хонсю, Кюсю и Сикоку, а временные рамки охватывают период окончания Сэнгоку Дзидай. В роли даймё — лидера одной из враждующих группировок — игрок должен вести боевые действия, заниматься экономической политикой и вести дипломатическую игру, чтобы добиться главной цели игры: объединения феодальной Японии в единое государство под властью клана игрока.

В сухопутных сражениях игрок командует армией. Армия делится на отряды, максимальное число отрядов — двадцать. Каждое подразделение имеет свои преимущества, недостатки, стоимость обучения и общий уровень эффективности.

Подразделения имеют определённый моральный уровень, который может увеличиваться, если битва проходит удачно, или уменьшаться при тяжелых потерях, гибели офицеров или в случае смерти генерала.

Осады принимают в учёт архитектуру японских замков, которая отличается от своих европейских аналогов. Японские замки состоят из нескольких террас, окружённых стенами. Высота каждой террасы зависит от рельефа. В Shogun 2 нет нужды строить осадные машины, хотя в состав армии и могут входит мангонелы (катапульты) и европейские пушки, которые не могут перемещаться во время боя. Все пешие войска способны карабкаться по стенам во время штурма замка. Чтобы захватить замок совсем необязательно уничтожить всех защитников. Достаточно пробиться к центральному зданию и захватить его. Войска также могут поджечь замковые врата, чтобы иметь более прямой доступ в замок и позволить кавалерии вступить в бой с защитниками. Также, кавалерия может спешиться чтобы залезть на стены. Крепостные башни могут быть захвачены во время штурма, как и различные здания присутствующие за стенами замка. Например, захват фермы повышает выносливость армии в этой битве, тогда как захват додзё лучников пополняет запасы стрел и аммуниции.

В «Shogun 2» разработчики вернули подбадривающие речи генералов перед боем. Все речи — на японском с субтитрами. В ней по возможности максимально точно описывается ситуация: кто противник, количество обеих армий, честь вражеского даймё, качества своего клана, и т. п.

Чтобы стать сёгуном, клану необходимо захватить и удержать Киото, а также необходимое количество провинций.

reviewText:
Katanas, Nodachi and Pikemen, learn the difference between each weapon.
Learn that all japanese weapons are two handed even if they are small, unless of course it is a dagger.

reviewText:
This is my favorite game in the entire Total War series; it is very polished and provides huge replay value.

The game is set in the height of the Sengoku Jidai period of Japan. You may choose between a selection of well-known clans/domains (Oda, Tokugawa, Takeda, etc) and proceed to conquer the surrounding provinces, with the ultimate goal being to overthrow the Ashikaga Shogunate and then consolidate your own rule.

The game's community is still decently sized, multiplayer is active, and has a steep skill curve.
Shogun 2's multiplayer allows for large strategic variation. Terrain, precise unit control, special abilities, multiplayer character leveling, even individual unit stat customization is all there, and delivers great fun.

Unlike more recent Total War games, all of the DLC is worth the money, especially Fall of the Samurai.

Did I mention that the soundtrack is awesome?

A must have for any Total War fan.

reviewText:
Easily the best Total War game since Rome and Medieval II (and it may be better than both of those), Shogun 2 takes the franchise back to where it began: Japan's Sengoku Era. You play as one of the great Daiymo lords struggling to unite the country. This is not the easiest of tasks, and it is one that inevitably involves a great deal of violence since ultimately there can only be one Shogun. Unlike previous TW games, once you reach a certain level of strength in the campaign, all of the other factions unite to fight against you, leading to an intense mid-late game. Since past TW games tended to get far too easy once you conquered enough, this is actually rather refreshing to see since it staves off boredom. Overall, the gameplay is similar to all other TW games, except here it is more polished, more focused, and altogether better than previous installments.

It also has a rather unique and well-designed multiplayer system which, while unfair at times if the matchmaker puts you up against vastly more experienced foes, at least manages to give a player reasons to keep playing it. I'm not sure if anyone still plays the multiplayer, but i'd hope so. Besides, i've been given to understand that Creative Assembly made a mess of Rome 2's multiplayer (among other things), so Shogun 2's is probably a superior experience.

There are flaws in this game though. The AI here is much better than in past TW games, but it still has its dummy moments. People who have crazy-good PC's may be irritated to find out that this game at its maximum settings might be too much for their computers to handle. The larger your empire gets the more micromanagement you have to do, which, although no different from previous TW games, still can be annoying for those who just want to fight the battles. Lastly there are bugs and crashes that, while not too frequent, are still frustrating when they happen.

If you have an interest in this franchise but have yet to try it out, Feudal Japan in general, or really just well-made games, then this is worth checking out.

reviewText:
A wonderful return to form for the Total War series. Every game in the Total War series since Rome has been rushed, buggy, and had horrible AI and spotty decision making, reeking of an unfinished game. No longer. They have finally broken the mold with this game.

There are problems. Don't get me wrong. It's not perfect - but it's complete. Your units follow your orders to the death. There are few movement bugs. The AI is competent enough to challenge you in strategic warfare, actually raising armies and attempting to take territory. They will not shy from engaging you. Nor does the campaign hand you the keys to victory as every other Total War game (since Rome) seems to.

Buy it. For the love of god. Vote with your wallet. Show Sega that the only thing they have to do is SIT BACK AND LET THEIR DEVELOPERS WORK.

reviewText:
My favourite game from the Total War series had always been Shogun, I spent years hoping that they would bloody make another one already... And here it is :D

If you love the fundamental core at the heart of each Total War game; the battle simulator, then this is the best one yet. It derives its depth and complexity from the tactics available to you and not just relying on a large amount of cosmetically differing units (ahem Empire) on the campaign map. Its got the most accessible and worthwhile multiplayer in the series, along with the classic take-control-of-Japan campaign now with Clan leaders, traits and a lot more personality. Its got Coop :D

If you have a half decent gaming pc capable of running this beast, and you are excited by dem tactics, get this game now ;p

reviewText: This is the highest quality game in the Total War series, even after the addition of Rome 2. This game shines in the battle sequences, where employing different tactics and strategies can give you the upper hand, even in battles that would otherwise be lost if auto-resolved. You feel in absolute control over every aspect of battles, and when you lose you feel like it was because of something you did, not due to some mechanic of the game. The game is fantastic in single-player, but there is also a multiplayer meta-game, where you create a general and battle against others for more money and different troops. This mode isn't as popular, but is still functional, and entertaining to fight friends with.\n\nPlay this game for the battles and military strategy. Do not play this game for diplomacy and nation building. While those are somewhat important for the grand campaign, they only tie together each battle.

reviewText: There is an easy appeal to TOTAL WAR: SHOGUN 2, more so than any entry in the TOTAL WAR series besides perhaps the original ROME (which, in my opinion, was the greatest strategy game of all time). It plays like a massive Hollywood samurai epic, featuring a simple yet layered management interface, yet never forgets the sanctity of its source material - the original SHOGUN that launched the franchise. If anything, it is a massive update to the original game, and as such it is ironically a downgrade to previous TOTAL WAR titles. And this is a good thing; referring specifically to the entries after MEDIEVAL 2 - EMPIRE and NAPOLEON - these were ambitious yet deeply flawed games that perhaps bit off more than they could swallow (something that is currently plaguing the equally ambitious ROME 2 that failed to follow the strides of its predecessor nor honor its masterful original).\n\nSHOGUN 2 rather addressed the issues of its predecessor and, to Creative Assembly's credit, took a humble path and simplified itself to not only a feasible light, but an infinitely satisfying one. Conquering and running your empire is now easier than ever, and in the process you actually recieve a fairly accurate history lesson that glorifies the grit as well as the spectacle of the samurai era. However, you'll find a fairly limited diversity in units as well as actual land area to conquer (which while historically accurate, can make you nostalgically hearken to the massive diversity of ROME and EMPIRE), and a by-the-book who beats who" battle gameplay. Despite this
date: there is something incredibly satisfying about watching - in the midst of a gigantic battle - two samurai engaging in single ceremonious combat
recommended: ending with one effortlessly stabbing the other through the neck and kicking him down like a total badass. And this is the appeal of the real-time battle interface (the other half of TOTAL WAR gameplay)
hoursPlayed: the incredible battle visuals that allow you to look at the whole picture from above like a bloodthirsty god or down to the individual combatants like someone fighting directly beside them on the field. While the graphics aren't exactly award-winning (probably the one thing ROME 2 has over this one)
voteText: the inherent satisfaction of watching and commanding these battles is as aesthetically appealing as it is culturally respectful to the samurai era.\n\nTo top off all the awesomeness
helpfulPercent: FALL OF THE SAMURAI is perhaps my favorite videogame expansion ever made
votesHelpful: refining the gameplay of the samurai era mode and bringing it to the gunpowder age - proving that for TOTAL WAR simplicity can be achieved for gun gameplay without delving into the needless complexities of EMPIRE. It is my preferred mode to the game (as I dont need to research gunpowder technology for fifteen years to recieve subpar firing squads)

reviewText:
Easily the best Total War game since Rome and Medieval II (and it may be better than both of those), Shogun 2 takes the franchise back to where it began: Japan's Sengoku Era. You play as one of the great Daiymo lords struggling to unite the country. This is not the easiest of tasks, and it is one that inevitably involves a great deal of violence since ultimately there can only be one Shogun. Unlike previous TW games, once you reach a certain level of strength in the campaign, all of the other factions unite to fight against you, leading to an intense mid-late game. Since past TW games tended to get far too easy once you conquered enough, this is actually rather refreshing to see since it staves off boredom. Overall, the gameplay is similar to all other TW games, except here it is more polished, more focused, and altogether better than previous installments.

It also has a rather unique and well-designed multiplayer system which, while unfair at times if the matchmaker puts you up against vastly more experienced foes, at least manages to give a player reasons to keep playing it. I'm not sure if anyone still plays the multiplayer, but i'd hope so. Besides, i've been given to understand that Creative Assembly made a mess of Rome 2's multiplayer (among other things), so Shogun 2's is probably a superior experience.

There are flaws in this game though. The AI here is much better than in past TW games, but it still has its dummy moments. People who have crazy-good PC's may be irritated to find out that this game at its maximum settings might be too much for their computers to handle. The larger your empire gets the more micromanagement you have to do, which, although no different from previous TW games, still can be annoying for those who just want to fight the battles. Lastly there are bugs and crashes that, while not too frequent, are still frustrating when they happen.

If you have an interest in this franchise but have yet to try it out, Feudal Japan in general, or really just well-made games, then this is worth checking out.

reviewText:
AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME

I made the mistake on holding off on this game for so long because (being a fan of Empire's style) I thought that feudal Japan felt like a boring distant culture I could not get into, let alone relate to, but after watching enough reviews with overwhelming praise for the game, I just had to give it a try...and I got sucked in.

Everything in this game is either perfect or darn near perfect.  From the music and voices to the artwork, this is a very immersive game.  Combat animations give the most fluid and interesting (and brutal) portrayals of combat I've ever seen in a Total War game (haven't played Rome 2 yet though)

The main tutorial teaches most of what you need to know, such as how to use the campaign map, the basics of attacking, but I would strongly recommend searching for and studying battle tips on youtube (and there are plenty!).  Just remember: Spear beats horse, sword beats spear, horse beats sword, bow beats everything at distance, and everything beats bow up close, and keep your general safe and close.  Naval combat is the game's only weakness, as early on it feels like its just archer platforms shooting eachother.  You'll be desperate to upgrade and get ships with cannons to spice it up.

Just don't do what I did on my nooby first try...expanding and recruiting too many too fast, running out of food and money, losing public order, and starting an early realm divide, A PERFECT NIGHTMARE  (It's actually pretty much common sense when governing the campaign map, so don't worry about stressful brainstorming on this)

All in all, this is a game every PC should have.  I'd recommend it to anyone who likes RTS games or would like to get into RTS games.  I also strongly recommend it to RTS fans who have been on the fence over getting this game.  It's worth every cent.  (Don't forget Fall of the Samurai though, some people say it's even better than plain Shogun 2)

reviewText:
Most likely the apex of the Total War series, Shogun 2 manages to hit almost every high point the series has had in previous installments. Shogun 2, despite trimming down some features like town management, manages to capture the previous games' glory without sacrificing much beyond excess tedium. Despite this, it still has a steep learning curve as in the previous installments. The more focused scope of the game allows for a much easier time of getting into the series, placing Shogun 2 as the first game that one should buy if they are interested in the Total War series in this reviewer's opinion.

Strengths:
Preserves the depth of the franchise without getting lost in the tedium.
Beautiful, engaging visuals with some heavily stylized artwork.
Preserves the culture of feudal Japan, doing it great justice.
Good mod support.
Focus on Japan ensures you understand every unit's purpose.

Weaknesses:
Relatively steep learning curve, despite having been more simplified.
Discouraging to new players, as the game can take some time to truly start in force. (Not exactly a con for veterans)
Small focus on Japan, disallowing unit diversity.

Overall numerical rating: 9-9.5

reviewText:
One of the best strategy games about wars that I've ever played. Wars, it's what the game is all about. It's both the games strenght and it's flaw, what it lacks in economy, diplomacy, infrastructure or basically everything about kingdom management, it takes up in amazing battles.

Lead small contingent forces and ambush your enemy, inflicting severe harm before they can reach your cities. Command your entire army, consisting of thousands of soldiers into glorious battles, burn down gates, climb enemy walls and crush your opponents. Why not send your agents of chaos while you're at it and decimate the enemy troops before your army reach them? Sabotage their county and leave them unable to recruit advanced troops or the gates and march your entire army at them, leaving no one left alive !

Recommend it for everyone seeking thrills in strategically fighting over massive battlefields with thousands of soldiers, with you as the supreme leader and general !

reviewText:
This is a excellent entry in the Total War Franchise. It offers a perfect combination of real-time and turn-based strategy, that will keep you playing for hours.

Pros:
-MODS!!!!!! (don't like how the vanilla game plays? then you will probably find a mod that suits you) I personally found the vanilla game to be good, but with certain mods installed my experience improved drastically.
-Amazing Animations
-Very authentic
-Amazing Graphics (Soldier, enviroment, building, ship model/textures)
-Competent AI in Campaign
-Decent AI in Battles
-Good amount of units (It is less than other Total War games, but you have to consider the fact that this Total War game is set in only one country)
-Campaign is straightforward and very easy to understand.


Cons:
-Requires a very good computer, (this can crash often if you are at minimum specs)
-Individual soldiers fight one-on-one
-Moving units in Groups doesn't always work too well. You'll have to micro-manage them.
-Too many siege battles in Campaign
-Naval Battles are not very fun
-AI can be pretty stupid, but it is not broken.
-Unlike other Total Wars, the campiagn can get repetitive. However this could be the fact that I play 500+ hours.

I highly recommend this game!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A huge improvement from older Total War games. Shogun 2 has a great design and creative layout. Once you get past the (not so hard) learning curve it is very hard to stop crushing your enemies, and trading wifes to save alliences.

If you havent played any of the total war games they essentually play like this, its composed of a strategic map view where you build your armies, manage your empires economy, organized your generals, and engage in diplomacy with other diamoes in futal japan. The other part of the game is when two enemy armies meet on the campaign map, they will engage in a real time tactical battle which will display thousands of soldiers engaging in ranged and hand to hand combat. All of this with really impressive combat animation. This game has come a long way from the original offering in Total War Shogun back in the year 2000. Naval battles, siege battles, and even ambushes all add to keep it fresh and interesting. Campaigns can take a single day, or up to weeks depending on the perameters you set.

Multiplayer:
So you can see how multiplayer has always been a really tough mode to include for the series. But Shogun 2 does a few things that makes it manageable. First you have the real traditional (and now) cooperative multiplayer campaign, a feature that Napolatin Total War lacked. This is where you can ally with a friend or even compete against them same as you would in a normal campaign with all the features. With each of your taking turns on the campaign map. And in battles you can even split control of armies just make sure you have plenty of time to go this full mode. However for people that like their gaming in shorter bursts you can now engage in a new mode called avatar conquest, where you can create your own general, create your own army and then engaege against other multiplayer generals. These wins and losses then apply towards a campaign map where your fighting for control of japan. WIth all these new features creative assembly has really found the perfect balance for legitimate multiplayer in this already epic game, extending its huge playtime already hundreds of hours to some ridiculous levels.

Graphics:
The element aspect of this game is amazing, I usually rate the graphics of games by their water graphics. The way the water moves from the current and wind, the shine from the sun and other light objects. Well I am very happy that this game gets it right. In naval battles the ocean currents crash against your ship if your not facing the against the current, you must pay attention to the wind to see if it will be easy to sail, etc.. The huge battles that play ontop of big moutainus regions and hilly lands are amazing to watch and control. All of the soldiers have visible combat animations by actual sword master. and this takes up upon thousands of troops at a time. A truly remarkable game.

94/100        94% Magnificent

reviewText: Truly an epic addition to the Total War series, this magnificent game moves the Total War battlefields to the Far East. The Singleplayer gameplay is centered around a Turn Based campaign map, where you are allowed to Macro your Economies, Commerce, Armies, Diplomacy, and Agents all on one easy to follow medium. One drawback is the lack of castle variation or construction ability, each siege battle will have the same castles for each stage of construction achieved in the province; However in other modes in the game, you may choose to preload a unique castle for one battle. The actual battles themselves take place in a Real Time Strategy environment where the player must field their units in battle against enemy forces. There are many types of battles; Sieges, Skirmishes, Night Battles, Ambushes; Each battle providing a different experience and strategy. Countless units will allow you to construct a diverse army capable of accommodating for any possible enemy strategy. The online play has obviously seen better days considering the date of release; However one can still find a competative game here and there. The Avitar campaign feature was truly one of the best facets of the game, allowing for players to join clans with their friends, and play a competative campaign style map which eliminated all Macro management, and focuses only on the battles to consider the outcome of each turn. The player then gains veteran units to field in later battles, and also the opportunity to upgrade each veteran unit with unique abilities such as fire arrows, or the swooping crane. The game also allows for historical battles which actually have some historically accurate information provided in the massive in game index. Trust me if you have any questions about how to do something in the game, it will be in that index. All in all this game will keep you entertained for hours, whether you enjoy playing solo, or multiplayer; there are endless opportunities to replay this game.

reviewText: In Total War: Shogun 2 you play as a daimyo on a quest to conquer all of Japan. Manage your provinces, beat back rebellion, train troops, and march against your foes in countless battles. Slowly you learn the in depth AI strategy, hill camping. The AI will surrender many men for their 1 troop of yari ashigaru to camp a hill. Fear not though, CA have provided the AI with money and no fear of rebellions, ability to gain the best agents without the need to train them.\n\nIf you are looking to get into the Total War series then Shogun 2 would be the best entry next to Rome, just don't expect all too much from the enemy AI, if there is a hill, they will camp it. Over the course of playing you will start to understand how the AI reacts to different situations and game things that way. The next bet would then be on multiplayer but I'm too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to get into that part of the game.

reviewText: Truly an epic addition to the Total War series, this magnificent game moves the Total War battlefields to the Far East. The Singleplayer gameplay is centered around a Turn Based campaign map, where you are allowed to Macro your Economies, Commerce, Armies, Diplomacy, and Agents all on one easy to follow medium. One drawback is the lack of castle variation or construction ability, each siege battle will have the same castles for each stage of construction achieved in the province; However in other modes in the game, you may choose to preload a unique castle for one battle. The actual battles themselves take place in a Real Time Strategy environment where the player must field their units in battle against enemy forces. There are many types of battles; Sieges, Skirmishes, Night Battles, Ambushes; Each battle providing a different experience and strategy. Countless units will allow you to construct a diverse army capable of accommodating for any possible enemy strategy. The online play has obviously seen better days considering the date of release; However one can still find a competative game here and there. The Avitar campaign feature was truly one of the best facets of the game, allowing for players to join clans with their friends, and play a competative campaign style map which eliminated all Macro management, and focuses only on the battles to consider the outcome of each turn. The player then gains veteran units to field in later battles, and also the opportunity to upgrade each veteran unit with unique abilities such as fire arrows, or the swooping crane. The game also allows for historical battles which actually have some historically accurate information provided in the massive in game index. Trust me if you have any questions about how to do something in the game, it will be in that index. All in all this game will keep you entertained for hours, whether you enjoy playing solo, or multiplayer; there are endless opportunities to replay this game.

reviewText:
Shogun 2 is a fun, fast paced and exciting game to say the least. The multiplayer is great, the campaign is great, the units are great and the varying factions are all great. Shogun 2 is the second version of the shogun series and one of the newer Total War games. It is unique in the use of its DLC to expand on the base game and features other great unique features that older Total War games lack. Now, although medieval Japan is not my variety historical period I loved the look of the game and got into lots of information about it before buying it finding it to be worth it. Sadly my system is not the best at running it but in playing it I've enjoyed it, especially the multiplayer for what I could run smoothly. With co-op systems, avatar general and army building combined with leaderboards that can be attributed to Steam groups the system is a great improvement to the Total War games before it. I personally stuck to the multiplayer for most of my playing period with the game unlike in previous games where I stuck to the single player nearly the whole time. Multiplayer alone would still make this game good. Unit choices are another really great aspect which works with the varying factions too. Their is even one on the president! I won't give you any clues on what its called though. The other great thing about the game not mentioned yet is the graphics. The general look of the game is great despite my poor specifications which shows that it is great beyond what I considered already good as higher specification computers will have an even better sight. To summarise the good points-

- Improved multiplayer
- Good DLC that works well improving on the base game
- Great graphics
- Interesting and varied number of units
- Unique and original factions
- Great Campaign
- Great Historical battles with huge clashes and great explanations to them

Now to the bad. The game is hard to run for me and since my system is alright I would say it may be an issue for some others out there. Lowering the quality of the game helps, but the single player can lose the nice look due to the game struggling. Also, from what I saw, the early mulitplayer battles are awful if you don't have riflemen as they are incredibly over-powered.  The DLC, although improving on what the game offers greatly is a bit unfair at times to those without it. Without DLC its hard to beat armies who have them and since most players have already got high in the rankings late entries may find the first ten to twenty matches a bit of a slaughter on them. I got some riflemen and soon found I was the one slaughtering others which became fun though, so it worked out! To summarise the bad points-

- Over-powered DLC at times
- Specification is slightly too high for some lower specified computers.

So the game is great despite its obsession with paying more on upgrades in and out of the game to make your experience more pleasing in combat I would easily score this game a 4/5, 8/10 or 80%. It shows Total War games to be improving in many aspects and is definetly a great strategy game overall.

reviewText:
The first Total War game I ever played was the orginal Shogun (many years ago) and I've played the series ever since.

The orginal Shogun is quite simplistic and rather dated now, in terms of the things that newer Total war games have to offer, however my love for that game did lead me to buy Shogun 2.

And I've not regretted that decision.

Shogun 2 is by far one of the best Total war games I've played. It takes everything that is good about TBS games and adds to it;

~ Weather conditions play more of a factor in battles, adding realism. Thus players need to adapt better strategies when deploying troops.

~ Naval battles have been expanded and mechanics are much improved from Empire.

~ The overall feel to the game is improved. Clans and Generals seem to have different personalities which enhances your intrigue for the game.

~ The Campaign map on Empire, I felt was too large and I personally seemed to get bogged down with watching things such as finances and overseas settlements than actually trying to dominate the map.

Shogun goes back to focussing on the War" element
date:
that made Rome and Medieval 2 so popular but it adds more in depth realism where it's wanted most; battles.

~ Creating an avatar and unlocking units on online multiplayer keeps your drawn once you're through with campaign.

By far one of the best games I own. Must buy for TBS gamers and Total War fans.





"

reviewText:
For starters, if you are looking to buy a good strategy game then buy Shogun 2 instead of Rome 2 atm. This is because Shogun 2 has a way better AI than Rome 2 and you can have a decent amount of fun watching the sometimes, hilarious cutscenes that it shows you of, for example your ninja being detected and stuck in a wall etc.

Also I thought that the naval combat on here was beautiful and intriguing to watch (imo). So if you are looking for a good strategy game, then I would recommend Shogun 2 (or Rome 1 which is my favourite strategy game ever).

EDIT:3/13/2016, Now that I have more hours in Shogun 2, I can say that this game is the most polished total war game to date (without mods). I also definitely recommend getting fall of the samurai, it has fluid gun combat and is actually very different from the base game, since navies have a very important role to play with the added naval bombardments that can leave an army in a land battle in dissaray. Fall of the samurai is the perfect example of what an expansion should be.

reviewText: While I am not a fan of the Warscape engine in terms of the management of settlements, this is still a fine addition to the Total War repertoire. With beautiful scenery and units only disrupted by the brutality of the combat, this is a visual feast. There is also fantastic small details in the combat, I love me dem Samurai duels! The game lacks the epic scope of previous campaigns due to its setting but it is still slick and the battles are the most rewarding yet.
